Posts.Content: Feb 9, 2010 09:02AM - edited Feb 9, 2010 09:04AM by robyn33 Everyminute, somehow you have managed to answer a question for me that has been bothering me since last weekend.  I had a chance to visit my next door neighbor (young, 28, beautiful, and due to have her first baby in about 3 weeks).  I could tell that she was very excited to be finishing up her pregnancy.  She should be.  I am very excited for her and her husband.  However, the ENTIRE TIME that I was at her house--which was about 3 1/2 hours--she complained about how "big" she was, how she can't eat what she wants, can't drink what she wants, how much her tummy hurts, how hard it is to move, etc...  I mean, she didn't stop the whole time I was there!  I couldn't figure out until now why I was bothered so much by it.  I know that women in the late terms of their pregnancies are uncomfortable and all, but I felt kinda bad that I was put out by her complaining.  Now I understand why.  Thank you...  I don't feel so bad any more.  :-)
Posts.Title: You know what I hate...rant! everyminute cherneski

Posts.Content: Oct 25, 2008 03:26PM robyn33 wrote: Hi all.  I finished my 6th round of TCH on October 17th and have a meeting with my radiation oncologist on Monday to set up my treatment.   I, too, am anxious to get going so I can finish up and get back to "life."
Posts.Title: November 2008 Rads Group HensonChi Ivy

Posts.Content: Feb 11, 2009 03:37PM robyn33 wrote: I had taxotere with carboplatin (TCH)--six rounds.  I had tingling in my feet towards the end of chemo that lasted for about three months.  At one point the tingling almost hurt and would keep me awake at times.  I don't notice any tingling anymore, and the numbness is limited to the bottom of my toes and is very, very minimal.  There is hope.
Posts.Title: Another question..taxotere left overs Fitztwins LisaSDCA

Posts.Content: Sep 2, 2009 09:20AM robyn33 wrote: Hi, I am a fellow stage IIIa girl...  I was diagnosed in May 2008.  Reconstruction was always on the table for me--in fact I was referred directly to a plastic surgeon by my breast surgeon.  I had tissue expanders placed at the time of my bilateral MX.  You must live your life with confidence that you have killed the beast.  Don't waste time denying yourself things because you are afraid that breast cancer may return.  It may--I certainly live with that fear. But I try to push it to the back of my mind.  The fear seems farther and farther away every day.  I just had lat flap surgery at the end of June.  Even my radiated breast looks better than ever (my PS worked a miracle on that one).  I'm so glad I had the surgery because it lifted my spirits and makes me look whole again. Go for it--you deserve it after all you've been through!  :-)  Carpe' diem!!!!!
Posts.Title: Any stage 111ers had breast reconstruction alaskalady RBodem

Posts.Content: robyn33 wrote: I am completely baffled by my husband's reaction last night to the fact that I have told my next door neighbor and my ex-husband (father of my two oldest children) that I have cancer.  He was upset because he felt that it should be "private" and that those people had no right to have that kind of information about our family situation.  WHAAAAAT????  Do we creep around in silence when someone has a heart attack or a stroke, for example?  I wasn't aware that I had something that needed to be kept secret--how will I do that anyway, when I show up outside or in public without hair or eyebrows???  Anyone give me some insight on this? Dx 5/13/2008, IDC, 2cm, Stage IIIA, Grade 2, 5/15 nodes, ER+/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Husband doesn't want me tell tell anyone! robyn33 roseg

Posts.Content: May 29, 2008 04:57PM robyn33 wrote: I would really like to know what the book title is.  Thank you!
Posts.Title: Husband doesn't want me tell tell anyone! robyn33 roseg

Posts.Content: May 27, 2008 04:02PM robyn33 wrote: Thank you all for sharing your perspectives.  My husband normally is a strong individual and doesn't like others to perceive weakness in him.  I can understand that having to deal with other people's reactions to this information in turn forces him to have to deal with it, too.  It is interesting that Anne mentioned that folks may feel uncomfortable talking about diseases involving the breast, uterus, prostate, etc... My husband brought this up last evening when he mentioned that, if he had prostate cancer, he would not tell anyone except those who absolutely HAD to know--and certainly not our neighbor!!!  I guess I never realized that there were places in the body to get cancer that were inappropriate to talk about in public.  Whoops!  My bad!  I intuitively know that I will need support for myself and family through this ordeal.  I think the people I know and love, for the most part, would want this opportunity to help out at this time when it is so genuinely needed.  And, yes, I feel strongly that my children should feel free to talk about their feelings with whoever they feel comfortable. I don't want them to feel isolated during this episode of their life just because I (or my husband) want to be "private."  While I am the one that has been diagnosed, my family will be coping with all of the stages of treatment and recovery, also, but in a different capacity.
Posts.Title: Husband doesn't want me tell tell anyone! robyn33 roseg

Posts.Content: May 30, 2008 04:54PM robyn33 wrote: Sherri, I also did receive some "not-so-good" news at that Dr. appt., too.  He said my pathology report showed that my cancer was Her2 positive.   I must say that I'm a little freaked out about that after reading some information on the internet.  I know there are some ladies on this board who are dealing with Herceptin treatments and chemo right now, but I was obviously hoping I could avoid the chemo.  Does anyone know if it is "automatic" that there will be chemo-herceptin with Her2 positive cancers?
Posts.Title: Husband doesn't want me tell tell anyone! robyn33 roseg

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2009 08:09AM robyn33 wrote: Hi Jan, Assuming that your body metabolizes tamoxifen (need a test to confirm), tamoxifen may be a good option.  I understand feeling very apprehensive of taking the drug when considering the possible side effects--I agonized over the decision for the six months that I was undergoing chemo and radiation due to stage III IDC.  Ultimately, I decided to give it a chance after I had the test to confirm that my body metabolizes the drug, and I've been taking tamoxifen for a month.  So far, I don't have any side effects that cause me a lot of discomfort or concern. Some women don't have side effects, but some women do.  The benefits for me far outweighed the potential for side effects as the hormonal therapy may reduce my risk of recurrence by abou 30% or so.  Good luck with your decision...
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen concerns - patient with Atypical Ductal Hyperplasia JanW wallace101

Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2010 08:31AM robyn33 wrote: Just chiming in with hopes and prayers for good news at your appointments today, Everyminute and DC Mom.  :-) Robyn
Posts.Title: its all about me everyminute KerryMac

Posts.Content: Jun 15, 2009 03:19PM robyn33 wrote: Somebody here mentioned TCH.  That may be an option since it's considered to be less cardio toxic than AC/TH.  I did the TCH regimen and, although it was no walk in the park, it was doable.  Your Mom may consider this with her oncologist if she would like to try chemotherapy.  At any rate, the AI and herceptin are a "must do" and the effects from those are something that a person can learn to put up with.  Good luck with your mother's decision.  I know that trying to decide on which course to take can be mind-numbing.
